newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia GST support doubled in six years - poll.
newsitem.headline: Australia GST support doubled in six years - poll.

text.p: Support for a goods and services tax (GST) in Australia has almost doubled in the past six years, according to a newspaper poll published on Tuesday.
The Australian newspaper's Newspoll found that 45 percent of voters supported a GST, compared with 27 percent in June 1991 when the conservative Liberal Party first adopted the concept.
The poll showed only 33 percent of voters now rejected a GST, compared with 58 percent in mid-1991.
It found 22 percent of voters were undecided.
"The survey provides a dramatic boost to (Prime Minister) John Howard's plans to sell the new tax," the newspaper said.
The poll showed the strongest backing for a GST came from Liberal-National coalition supporters, voters from households with high annual incomes, and full-time workers.
Last Wednesday, Howard endorsed the possibility of a GST as the government began a formal campaign for tax reform with the launch of an inquiry into the issue.
He also promised to produce a tax policy before the next election due by mid-1999.
The GST was blamed for the coalition's failure to oust the Labor government in 1993 after 13 years, despite the poll being viewed as an unloseable election.
The Newspoll surveyed 1,147 voters around the country by telephone over the last weekend.
